text:
News Feature | September 3, 2015 How To Deal With Recent Adjustments To The TCPA Marketing Guidelines 
By Christine Kern , contributing writer Infographic highlights how to avoid TCPA violations and mitigate compliance risk. 
On July 10, 2015, the FCC released new guidance strengthening consumer protection under the Telephone Consumer Protection Act (TCPA), a 1991 law protecting Americans against unwanted harassment from robocalls, autodialed telephone calls, and even SMS. These regulations were effective immediately, and potentially will have a dramatic impact on marketing nationwide. 
These new regulations mean that companies must re-evaluate their marketing and collection practices to prevent violations and mitigate compliance risk. In the long run, it will pay off for companies to invest in verification and to implement outbound dialing strategies that are data driven. 
In a recent infographic , Neustar , a real-time information services and analytics company, highlights what businesses need to know to avoid the dark cloud of costly TCPA violations and mitigate TCPA compliance risk. 
Compliance challenges are greater today as a result of connected, on-the-move consumers. Every year, some 2.1 million people legally change their names; 16 million people change addresses; 45 million people change at least part of their contact information; and 75 million people change phone carriers. 
Noncompliance or violation of the TCPA guidelines is expensive. Fines per unsolicited call, text message, or facsimile range between $500 and $1,000 and lawsuits can cost tens of millions of dollars. In 2014, TCPA violations were the top complaint to the FCC, and 2,336 lawsuits were filed. 
By ensuring TCPA compliance, companies will build trust with their customers. The recent history of violations has led to an environment of distrust, with 91 percent of American adults believing that consumers have lost control over how companies collect and use their personal data, and 40 percent of consumers taking steps to avoid online observation. 
By rebuilding trust, your company can retain control over customer data that can help improve brand loyalty and ultimate result in higher revenues. 
As the infographic concludes, “the TCPA’s new regulations mean companies must carefully consider their marketing and collections strategies, but doing so pays off in dividends by implementing data-driven outbound dialing strategies and investing in verification. Reaching the right person is more than a legal TCPA best practice; it’s an investment in your operational effectiveness and brand reputation.” Like what you are reading?
